div.p:
104
Trentham
Thursday 14th . Jany . 1819
You see we are here still - Mr . & Mrs .
Sneyd and Emma returned home
on tuesday - but Lord & Lady Stafford
expressed such an earnest wish that
we should stay a little longer that
finding Mrs . Sneyd would not take
it unkindly I consented - Lady
Elizabeth when I told her I had de
termined determined
to stay leaped from the
ground at least 18 inches & no
eyes could doubt the expression
of joy in her beautiful countenance
nor could any ear mistake the
sound of the clapping of her hands
- She is so kind to Honora and
Fanny & seems to value them
so justly & so to enjoy their compa
ny company
that even independently of
Ld . & Lady Stafford I would have staid
for her sake - But before I go
on any farther let me put your mind
at ease dearest mother about Fanny's
health - Her cold is going off - her
own looks are coming on - The pink
shell color is gaining & spreading over
the turnip cheek - & the pleased and
pleasing expression is lighting in those
of which Admiral Pakenham said -
nothing but the truth - She has
ridden out these last two mornings
on a nice pone y with Lady Elizabeth
- the rest of the morning she has past
in trying to take a likeness of Lady
Elizabeth - She & I sit up in Lady E's
comfortable little room (about the
size of your cabinet but very light) -
and I talk while Fanny draws &
we are all delightfully happy &
agreeable of course - Honora mean
time meantime
is in the library drawing in
water colors under Lady Stafford's eye
& instruction - Lady S. has been doing
a drawing on purpose to shew her
her method - She draws beautifully
105
and is like yourself about her drawings
perfectly free from all vanity or
care about them & from all affecta-
tion affectation
of humility - I would not for
any consideration have missed
this near & intimate view of her
character & domestic habits - What
an instinct for work & genius - What an an intuitive glance
into both head & heart that dear
father of mine possessed -

- It is impossible to tell you how kind
Lady Stafford has been to us - And
you would be still more satisfied
- as I am - on Honora & Fanny's ac-
count account
than on my own if you could
see how they are treated - not as
appendages to an authoress - but
as persons standing upon their
own merits & their own powers
of pleasing in conversation and
society - Lady Stafford has found
many most gratifying occasions
for expressing this - She has repeatedly
said to me What amiable, sensible
pleasing young women those two sis-
ters sisters
of yours are - how unlike com
-mon common
missies ! -

of Honora she said to me - " She is I shd .
think a most trust worthy young per-
son person
- one on whom one could depend
that her head wd . not turn in any si-
tuation situation
- steady - sensible - - like
her cousin Miss Sneyd in face & figure
& something in manner.

Fanny she particularly likes
- " She answers one gives one such
sensible answers when one asks
her any thing - She is a most pleasing
intelligent person - And very pretty -
(disqualifying speech of mine) - Oh more than that - She is certainly
very pretty - Ld . Stafford says so - the
gentlemen all say so

Then Lord Stafford found her like
half a dozen Lady This's & That's -
" I hope those ladies are all people
you like tolerably? "
" Tolerably! - said Lord Stafford particularly - They
are some of our most admired beau-
ties" beauties
- Then liking that she should be
so much with Lady Elizabeth & with
106
Lord Francis says more than
all these compliments -

Lord Francis is very clever and original
& simple & affectionate & fond of his
sister & as far from a dandy of any
kind - solemn - or vain - as can be
conceived - His drawings & his poetry
would both be excellent even if a
Lord did not own the happy lines

I am afraid you will think
that I am exaggerating & that I
have fallen too suddenly in love
with all these people - But I assure
you I have not colored even to the
life in representing their kindness
- nor have I nor dare I repeat
to you half the handsome things
Lady S. has said to me of Fanny .

I am just returned from a walk
in which Fanny & her being so well informed was great part of
the subject matter of Lady Staffords
conversation - And she ended with
saying " - " That Mrs . Edge-
worth" Edgeworth
must be a woman of great
" merit " - These words were cetainly
106
comfortable to me - for in the midst of
all the pleasure I had felt in Fannys
praises I had one uneasy regret
that they were not addressed to
that dear mother who best deserved
to have the exquisite delight of
hearing them - I seem to reap the
harvest sown by another - But
believe me though I am proud at the
harvest home & though you have
trusted me with the I have the
common honesty to say this rich
harvest is not of my sowing -

Every hour of every day apro-
pos apropos
to every thing picture, book
tree shrub & flower we wish you
were here - There is so much you
could tell Fanny & so much she
must lose of all she sees from
not having you with her! - But
I will be content - God bless you
dearest friend for trusting me with
her - And hitherto at least this
beginning promises well - The plea
sure pleasure
107
I have felt and the success she
has had is beyond my most sanguine
expectations -

I have not time to attempt any de-
scription description
of the beauties or magnifi
cence magnificence
of this place Park - or House -
- pictures - and whole estabish-
ment establishment
- that must be for hereafter
- But just NB - 10 livery servants
and four servants out of livery
- in black - these last only appear in the sitting
rooms - or stand in the hall &
antichambers con-ti-nu-ally -
- But the magnificence does not
interfere with the comfort - It is
splendid happiness - not splendid
misery

We go home to Byrkley Lodge tomor-
row tomorrow
- and Lady S sends her horses
first stage with us - We shall
call to pay a visit to Mrs . Cameron
who is at Mr . Butts -
These last 2 days quite alone -
except Mr . Ralph not John Sneyd -
(dont like) -

Send me news for Lady Spencer about
Saffron Castle
- and pray ask Harriet to look for
any letters of Scottsor Bannatynes
that she can find & send them in
the first packet to me for people are
so curious to see anything of Walter
Scotts that this gives me means of
obliging them

Heaphy has written Miss Sneyd such
a letter about CharlottesCharlotte's drawings! -
I will send it you per first packetPray send me the drawing you
promised to copy for Joanna
Baillie of Harriet carrying Pakenham

- That careless Fanny forgot
to forget deliver to me a packet
of letters till this moment
one from you - one from Paken
ham Pakenham
on my birthday with his
wonderful little lines - Thank him
dear little fellow - I will write to
him in my next - At present I
must say Goodbye for Lord S waits
to frank
